Remsen
Dear Brother Henry,
As I am not at all anxious to be obliged to listen to your bragging when you came home about your not having received one letter from home, all this time and as this is the last week of said term in which I shall now have an opportunity at redeeming my letter writing character I have taken the liberty of commencing a letter at this late date hoping that it may not only reach you in time, but that it may also be acceptable if not really looked for. I am looking forward with a great deal of interest and expectation to the two weeks which shall succeed this: Anna and you will probably be able to surmise the reason so I will not take the trouble to explain. --
How do you feel about the new field of action into which you seem to expect to enter? Only think, Harry, how much influence it will be yours to exert in these precious young minds which will for these months be placed so entirety under your guidance. And remember, dear brother, that it 
P.S. - Tues. morning Nov. 6. - I intended to have written to Anna this morning but as father has written to her and as they are in a hurry to send to the mail. I guess I shall not now have time. Give my very very best love to her and ask her to please forgive me for not writing to her this time. But tell she should not be at all anxious about us, lest we should be suffering from fatigue from reading her "many long letters" as I hope we shall be able to prove to her next time.
Good bye bub, dont' forget your sister who is two years older than yourself. Mary and Cynthia send each a little bundle of love to you Anna and sister E's family. —
Transcriber's note: writer must be Sarah Ann Everett, who was two years older than Henry. RMR

will, in a measure, be yours to decide into which of those "two paths" which "before mankind are free" those dear children shall enter. That you may be enabled to direct them into that faith whose "end is peace" is the prayer of your sister. 
Mary wen t to P.__ with father yesterday afternoon: they did not come home until after evening service. Mary said she had four invitations to stay over night, so you see you are not going among people that are cold and heartless. She did not accept either of them however, but came back with father, like a good girl, as she is. — 
Have you had any snow in Whitesboro yet?  the fields around here are beginning to look white. Stern winter is fast approaching with his chilly breath and snowy rales? . I love winter, it is so wild and fearless: and then the long evenings and cheerful fires which it brings, who can think of them without delight? But enough of this. Give my best love to Elisabeth and brother B. and to their presious babies. Also to Mrs. Butler; I wish she could visit us before she goes east. 

Now, Henry, as I have written enough to be able to say I have written you a letter, and as my strength does not seem to approve of my writing a great deal at all.
 I guess I will rather abruptly come to a close. —
  With much love, and in hopes of seeing you soon. 
    I remain your aff. 
     sister Sarah.

Remsen Nov. 28.1849.

Dear Sister Jane,

   I wish you were here seated by my bedside instead of being so many miles off. But this cannot now be much as we may wish it. Oh, Janey, I cannot tell you how very long the time has seemed to me since I had to confess to my own heart that you were indeed gone! Do you not remember how many times I said that I did not believe you would go? I know not why it was, but I could not bring myself to think that you were going, or indeed that you had gone after you started until I received a letter in your own writing saying that you were at South Hadley. How slowly the year passes away; only a little over two months have passed since you left us. But when you do return I hope that instead of lying here I shall be at the gate to meet you! Oh, then we will be twice happy!
   We commenced to write you a family letter last Sat. hoping to have it finished in time to send you before Thanksgiving day, but that is now impossible, and as we fear we shall not be able to finish it before next week some of our number being so much engaged in "the last of the month". I thought I would write you

a few kinds. I am very sorry, dear June that we all and especially that I have been neglegent in unity I little thought when we made the arrangement that I should have been behind hand, and indeed I do not think I would be if my head had not ached so badly. You do not know how much good it does us to receive your letters and how much we thank you for being so faithful in writing. I love to think of you on Tuesday evenings for then I know just how you are employed, and something how you feel. And I intend as soon as my health will permit us to consecrate the same time, for conversing with absent friends; O It will be so sweet to think that although so far apart, yet, at the moment we are whispering to each other!

  My health seems to be improving some, although very slowly. I am not yet able to sit up though but for fifteen minutes at a time, and as I do not after sit up more than once a day I am on the bed all most all the time. It is now nearly three months since I sat up to a meal; and I almost think that if Dr. would ever see to my waring those supporters again I should soon be able to sit up a good deal more. But perhaps as Dr. says they would hurt my back. I have but five blisters and very painful ones they were. The last time he was there he left me some irritating ointment to rub on my back instead of the blisters as they distressed me so much. I cannot tell yet how painful it will be. I still continue to use that instrument once a day and and

the woman with that every evening. I think they help and some my teeth have not troubled me more for several weeks but I have an almost constant pain in my head, which affects my eyes as much that I am not able to read or write that a very little, if it were not from that I would have written to you long before this. But I must close as I am getting very tired and my hand is unsteady that I learn you will kindly be able to make out what I have written. I hope you will not fail to write to me, then I when your time comes, and will write to you as soon as I can. With much love I remain your aff.  Sister Sarah.

Clinton W.C.   Nov. 25th, '51  
Dear Sister Jane,

 The object of my writing to you today is to scold you, to give you a real talking to, now dont say you dont deserve it, and try to plead off innocent, for you cant do it: you have earned it, and you richly merit a good long lecture.  Do you not begin to feel guilty, are you not sorry?  only think of it, leaving a poor sick sister, twenty six miles from home, three weeks without a letter.  Isn't it too bad?  Dr. says, write to her and give her a good scolding and put her in mind that there are folks in N.Y. state as well as in Mass., even if you have gone there.  I wish I could remember all he says, but I cant; for every evening when he comes from the P.O. and brings me the sad news of no letter he has something or other to say, and very often finishes with "tell her so, when you write."  if I could remember it all I rather think I should have no room to say anything else on the same sheet, so it is as well, perhaps, that my memory is poor.  You see the doctor lays all the blame on you and lets Mary go free, but I think she comes in for about an equal share.  he is not quite so well acquainted with her as he is with you, which, I suppose, accounts for it.  However, I think you stand upon the same ground and from your negligence deserve the same punishment.  Dr. has just been in, and wanted to know if I was writing to you; I told him, yes, and a real bad letter too: he said he didn't believe it, he didn't believe I would scold you at all.  he would change his mind if he only knew what I have written, but you think so?  Dear Jenny, I must confess, I cant scold you with all my

heart, for the thought will come in my mind, perhaps they are sick or something so is the matter, and I feel so anxious I almost forget what I am writing about.  Oh my dear sisters, I can hardly contain myself I want to see you so badly, but I must wait, I must be patient.  A few more months and, I trust, we will be together once more.  Oh, would that we might hope never again to be sepperated; but, alas: that cannot be in this world of parting; but let us even pray that after a few short years of meeting and parting here below, we may all meet in heaven never, never to part again.  Dr. has just been in again bringing a little note which he requested me to inclose to you; it will speak for itself. Remember you must mind the doctor.  O, Jenny, I wish you could have looked in upon us the other evening.  I guess you would have blushed a little, at least, I do not think you would have looked quite as sober as your likeness did, if you had  only been in the same position yourself.  There it stood leaning back against the tumbler, in all the dignity of the original and Dr. sitting right before it examining it at his lesure, rather an embaressing situation, was it not?  He said he wished he had Mary's too that he might compare them.  I hope I shall have it before long, as Robert has got it, and has promised to give it to me. Now Jenny dear, do write me a good long letter, won't you.  I believe a letter from you would do me more good then a weeks treatment; so you see it will not be lost.  I must close as I have something to say to Mary, and I am some tired now.  So good bye.  Your aff. sister.

Tuesday Afternoon
Dear Sister Mary,

  I have left half the sheet for you but if I am not able to fill it, I hope you will forgive me, and try to favey? it as full. 
  You see by my writing so much in one day that I'm gaining in strength decidedly. O, Mary, I do hope I may yet be well. Dr speaks quite encouragingly, and what is better still, I feel so much better. I suppose it will take a good while longer but I shall try to be patient, hoping for the best. I have been here now almost six months, a long time, do you not think so? 
  Last Wednesday evening I had a very pleasant visit from Robert and Miss Papa Mr. Roberts and Miss Smith. I was not much acquainted with the ladies, not having seen them since our donation, you remember they were at our house then; but still, I enjoyed the visit very much and made out to get a little more acquainted with them, which I was very glad to have the chance of doing. Miss P. and Miss S. spoke of you several times and they wished you could have been here with us; they told me to give their love to you when I wrote. — Susan started on her mission yesterday. It was a great trial to her and to all the family but they seemed very much resigned; they do not expect to see her ever again; although it is possible that she may return it is very doubtful. She was married just before she started, and so, of course had no wedding. Mr. Putnam, the gentleman that Susan married came here last Friday evening with his father and mother who came with him to attend the wedding and to see them start: they all seemed to feel very bad, but still were very calm and composed. Poor Susan she was a dear good girl; her mother

will miss her very much. Yesterday morning she was in my room and she said she wished she could see Jane before she left, or at least that she could have time to write to her; she wanted me to give her love to her when I write. —We have four patients here now, all ladies. Miss Royce, Mrs. Burchard, Mrs. C--la? and myself. Mrs. B. is in a very bad state indeed; she is crazy very crazy: but she is in the other part of the house, so I dont hear hardly anything of her. I suppose you remember hearing of her husband, the Rev. Jedidiah Burchard the revivalist. He stays here with her. I believe it is the first case of insanity they have had here; she has only been here about a week. Miss Royce is gaining Dr. seems quite encouraged about her now that she will be able to walk before long. Oh, Mary, I have had a compliment for you from here, and a first rate one too. I wish I could remember just how it went, but perhaps it is as well that I cannot, as it might make you vain. She thought you were a pretty smart girl anyway. — I cannot write much more as it is almost dark. I hope you will pardon the look of this letter, and that you will be able to read it. Excuse the size of the sheet you see it is not very good shape. I cut it short so that I could hold it better and left it wide so I could have more room. I am getting better as you may judge by the length of this letter. I hope that in the course of a few weeks to write that I am beginning to sit up. I stand my baths much better. All I have said to Jenny about writing, I say to you. Dear Mary, do write to me. I want a letter so bad. Dear sisters remember Sarah. Write soon With much love, Sarah

Remen, May 24./58

Dear Jamie, 

  We received your letter giving an account of that terrible storm and intended to have answered it immediately bur Nellie was taken sick, and I was most sick with toothache &c, so that we had but very little time to write. Thank you very much dear sister, for writing so soon. For it was precious to hear from you at your safety. Poor Anna, I had thought of her a great deal, she is always so timid when it thunders. May our good God preserve and

shelter you in every home! Do no be surprised if you see your letter in the Cen. Nellie has been quite sick for a few days; (it was a billious attack we think.) But is much better now. Matthew say if it was not for that she would have tried to have found time to write. She commenced a letter the day after we received yours but had no time to finish it. We have been washing today, that is I and Matthew. We hope if Nellie keeps gaining, she will be able to help us in a day or two. 

  We expect Mary home this week. We had a letter from them last week and she said

She thought at starting the beginning of this.

  Father left us a week ago tomorrow. We heard from from him from Buffalo and expect a letter tonight. I fear you will be much disappointed because Matthew is not with him; as we were in not having her go. But I hope it was all for the best. Excuse the hasty manner in in which this is written as I have but a few minutes to write. I have got all over my toothache and are feeling firstrate. We received (that is Lewis and Jane) a letter from Anna a week ago. They had written and I hope she has got theirs before this. Write soon.  Sarah.

Utica May 18, 1861

Dear Jennie,  

  I thought I would write you a few words this morning to say how I am getting along. My mouth is healing slowly. It was very sore for two or three days after I had the last teeth out, and it troubles me yet a good deal. I wish I could be home helping with the work but it seems hardly worth the while to go and come back again so soon. I hope I shall get all nicely through. next week that is as much as can be done now. I have no money to pay the dentist. As father what I had better do: will he send me some or can uncle Henry let me have some. I wish I knew how your are all feeling today. I got Anna's letter Thursday. i was glad to hear that 

in margin
Dear Anna I just remembered your letter containing that draft. I am very glad to get it as I had only three cents in my purse. I shall take good care of the change. We will see about those things. They went on Wed. I am so sorry about aunty. Had I better let my teeth go and come home? In haste, Sarah

you were getting along as well, I hope Mary has got better of her headache. Cousin Mary is pretty well for her, but little Laurie is quite sick with her teeth. She is some better today, but still is rather cross. I hope I shall have a letter from home today or Monday. I will write again in a few days. I have nothing in particular to say, so goodbye.

  I have not enlisted yet but if I do enlist for the union I intend it shall be for a longer term than three years.    Mary says you need not expect me until you see me and Thomas says I must not hurry but take my time and have it all done right which Mary says I must do if it takes me three weeks. They are all very kind and I am having a good pleasant time. 

Sarah.

Aug. 22, 1867
  New Hampton N.H.

Dear Sister Jennie,

 Yesterday, Eddie and I returned from our long thought-of trip to the White Mountains. We have been there some, no one can ever convince us that we have not. Eddie will tell you about the mist and the wonder that we saw there when he gets home. Anna really seems to be getting better, she appears stronger and her appitite is more regular and better. As we expected she felt better from her journey more after resting a few days than when we first got here. She took cold in evening from Bristol as it rained some. Her throat was quite sore and she felt badly for a while but she has got over it now and I feel very much encouraged about her. I will write more soon, we are very glad to get so many letters from home. 

Sarah.

Thursday Eve,
Dear Friends at Home
   I have been having a good, but short visit with Elizabeth and the children and intend to start home tomorrow morning. Will go through Boston and New York. Will get to Boston at 1-20 1.M. I intend to spend the Sabbath in New York. Will get home Wednesday noon if all is favorable. I had intended to write home from the mountains but we had so much to occupy our minds and moments that we deferred it. Will give you an account of that time again. We have had no rain since Sabbath eve. It is cloudy this evening and bids fine for a rainy day tomorrow. Johnnie says it has rained every Friday for five

weeks past. Elizabeth has had two letters from Mr Bulter this week, one yesterday and one today. He is well and has enjoyed his passage home on the Cuba, to sail for Boston the 23rd of Nov. 
We have been playing croquet today. had a fine time. The children all play well. But we had none of us played before. It is a splendid game. Anna has been playing also. I guess she is a little tired now. This visit is doing her & us all lots of good. Will have more to tell you when I get home. 
Your Son & Brother
E. W. Everett

New Hampton Sept. 14, 1867

Dear Sister Jennie,

  We have written one letter home this week but as Anna was not as well then as she had been I know you will be anxious to hear again. She has been feeling much better for two or three days and I do hope she will soon begin to gain in strength and flesh. Indeed she is some stronger now than when we left home but she isn't very fat but we cannot expect her to gain fast especially in flesh (I think Sarah is gaining in that respect --A) Anna is resting her now so of course I can write anything about her that I like. She keeps up pretty good spirits (I guess she means wine) most all the time, and isn't so awful smart as she used to be at home, that is with her needle but she is smarter getting up in the morning (and I am not so mart.) We have the bell ringing here before breakfast and sometimes they all ring before we are fairly up; first the Seminary rising bell rings at half past five, second the cow bells ring somewhere about six, 

in margin
Sunday afternoon. - I thought I would just write a word in this before I send it to let you know how we are today. 
Elizabeth did not feel well enough to go out today, she took a sweat this morning and feels a good deal better this afternoon. We hope she will be quite well in a few days. She seems to have taken cold when in Sixty? unclear afternoon and stood it very well. She really seems much better than she has for a long time. I think she has gained a good deal for a few days past. 
We are having very pleasant weather now This is a bright beautiful Sabbath How I would like to spend it in Steuben! S.

and thirdly the Sem. breakfast ell rings at half past six: so you see we can always tell when it is morning. Does Thomas get up as early as ever and who gets up next? 

  How are our apples getting along? have you commenced to use them yet? I fear there are not many on the trees, but I do hope you will be able to get some unclear before winter. The apples are very scarse around here, but we have had plenty of them so far. though they say that they are not nearly as good as they were last fall. How do the cucumbers prosper, and do you have any tomatoes?
  Jennie, what would you think of our going home through New York? Eddie thinks we would like it better there to return the way we came out. If we go that way we will probably stay there a few days, and we would like to have you send us cousin Thomas' address and also that of Mr. David Griffiths. Do you know whether cousin Elizabeth is unclear house now or not? Has Mrs. Griffith gone back yet? I have finished my calico dress and they all agree that it looks very pretty. I am glad that Mary has been having some help with the sewing. Elizabeth has not been very well for a few days.  She was quite sick this morning.

and last night but she is better now. the rest are all well. Have Jane Hughs and sister Jane got well yet? I hope it did not make them sick to go berrying. How I should have enjoyed being one of that party! did you go to the same place that we went last fall? and did you lead any one astray as you led me there? I should like to have been with you to attend the meetings this week and next. and to hear Mr. Jones preach and to see him again before he goes back to dear India. I think of all the meetings (the camp meeting and cymanfa) of these two weeks a great deal. God grant that this precious seed - time may be followed by a plentiful harvest! We have his sure promise " It shall not return unto me void." God is ready and waiting to do great things for us. but, "Thus saith the Lord God I will yet for this be inquired of by the house of Israel to do it for them." O, may a spirit of prayer and childlike trust rest on all the people. -------

  But I must not write much more it is cold up here, and I agreed to leave the last page for Anna. If I thought you were at all anxious about my health I would tell you that I am very weak indeed but as it is I will let it pass. Give a great abundance of love to baby Robbie Lewis folks and every one of you all. Have you heard from John since we came away. Yours &c Sarah A. Everett

As Sarah has left this page for me, and I have not written much lately, I guess I must try and write something, to redeem my character, if for no other reason. Sarah has written such a nice full letter, that I hardly know how to add anything - you know I dont want to take the shine off from her letter, but perhaps you will think there is no danger, so I will proceed as well as I know how. You will be sorry to hear that Elizabeth is poorly, but we are in hopes she will be better tomorrow. I wish Mary could see her. She has taken some cold, I think, and seems bilious. She seems better this afternoon, but has not much appetite. I hope you have had a good meeting this week, those of you who were able to attend. The weather has been very favorable, if it was the same there as it was here, - it has been very pleasant here nearly all the week; hope it will continue so next week. Who preaches in our church tomorrow? and next Sabbath? Wish I could be there to hear him. We received a letter two or three days ago, written on the inside by Jennie & Cynthia, and on the outside by Mary. It seems good to get something from each one, if only a little. I wish Robbie and Eddie would write again. We have had no letter from Lewis and Jane, but hope to soon. Give much love to father and mother and all.  Anna.
left margin:
If I didn't think there had been enough said on a poor subjectI would say something about myself. I am feeling much better than I did last week, indeed I have felt very well today — am about over my cold, played croquet with Father some today. this evening
upside-down at top:
we have been amusing ourselves and the little girls by playing all the little games we could each think of, such as magic writing &c., then we sang two or three tunes, as we do very often.

Turin Feb. 5. 1870.

Dear Jennie,

  Here we are safe and comfortable at brother Eddie's. Anna stood the journey quite as well as we could expect. She feels pretty tired but does not think she has taken cold.

Your letter has not got here yet so, of course, we were not expected. but it is all just as well. They were both quite well. Eddie looks better than I have seen him in some time. Mate looks well but she has a little sore on her arm which troubles

her a good deal just now. She burned it Monday and took cold in it but it seems to be getting better now. Robbie is going to spend the evening with us. He called this afternoon and took tea and then went home and got his book so he could study and visit. He is looking very well and happy. I forgot to bring the letter than his folks sent for him. I thought certainly I put it in my jacket with the toothbrush, but must have left it on the bureau up stairs in our room. Robbie wants his mother to come next week if she can. and he sends a special request to have her bring Maggie. He says he is anxious to see her. I will write

again in a day or two to let you know how Anne gets along. She is lying down now. Her food seems to taste good to her. We forgot to bring the powders Mary sent for Anna. I left them in a teacup on the table in the parlor. If you send the medicine please send Mary's letter too as Anne did not read it and I don't remember what she said about it. Love to all. Sarah A. Everett
Sunday evening. Anne feels quite tired but better than she did last night. I will write again soon. Tell Father that Eddie sent those H. books all right. -- Jennie, we forgot to bring those circulars of the kniting machines. What shall we do? S.A.E.

New York June 17.1875

Dear Sister Jennie,

  It is nearly dark but I thought I would commence a letter to you even if I am not able to finish it until tomorrow. We have a girl now, as I believe I told you, so I have more time to write than I did, though somehow I do not get at it very often. I had that P.O. order cashed today. I hope we shall be able to return your kindness sometime We do not spend much excepting for car fare &c but that takes a good deal as you know. We cannot go much without taking the cars, and it does us good, especially the sick ones, to go out as often as we can. We hope we shall have enough now until

we go home unless we stay longer than we intend. Cynthia will need a little; enough to pay her may home and two or three dollars besides. She wrote off a list of her expences that mother may see how she spent what she had. which I will enclose. We feel a good deal encouraged about her. Four weeks ago last Tuesday she had the last hard spell. William too has been very much better this past week. She has not wheezed hardly any and he has been able to walk a good deal more. Yesterday we had a very pleasant ride and visit. We went to Mr. Lewis Thomas' Jersey City. Mrs Jones and Rev Mr. Davies went with us. Eddie did not go on account of his school. The time will soon come for him to go home. He too will need money to pay his fare home. I hope it will not be very hard for you to spare so much. I must leave this now. William is going out for a little walk and I guess I will go with him.

Friday morning. We have had a nice rain this morning and it is raining some still. It was very much needed. I should think. We have not had much rain since we have been down. How is it with you? has it been very dry? It has been dry and cool here most of the time. William wants you to write more news. He says Mother writes the best letters of any of you. She tells how things are getting along. What interests you interests us. you know. I wish we could help you with the next Cen. but I hardly think we shall be with you then. As Cynthia and William seem to be gaining so nicely I think we ought to stay a little longer. We have not got Eddie a hat yet but we got a pair of shoes $2.50. we could not help getting them his old ones were all gone. Mary has not got herself any thing for summer, not even a hat., but she hopes to be able to in a few days. She has had a hard tug of it but things look a little better. She is getting along nicely with practice: she is quite busy

and very successful. but pay is slow coming in. If you can spare the Herald containing the account of the Anniversary exercises at Whitstown Sem. we should be very glad to see it. Has Jane Ann Williams visited with the Curch yet an is she waiting for the other girls? We were very glad to hear that they have come to the society. Are the prayer meetings well attended? I am glad you keep you class in Sunday school. How many does Anna have in her class? Are they going to have any thing the fourth of July? It is very lonely here when we do not hear from home for several days so please write as often as you can. Tell Mother that Eddie says he will talk enough when he gets home to make up for not writing. He is pretty busy and anxious now with his examinations. We are glad to here you tell her all the Steuben folks are getting along. Who bought Wm Roberts farm? With love to you all and to Lewis' folks from us all. I am as ever your aff. sister Sarah A.E.P.

New York July 27/75

Dear Sister Jennie,

  We received a letter from Mother with a few words from you yesterday morning. Many thanks for the check. We were very glad to get it. Mr. Scott cashed it so we had no trouble. I meant to have written yesterday, and now I will have to send a short letter as it is late, most tea time, and I want this to start today. Mary intended to have written to Mother and probably will soon. She is very busy with her practice and every thing else that she has on her hands. She has too much to do and especially too much care and anxiety. We were

glad to read John's letter. I enclose it in this. Mary intends to write to him soon. She and all of us think that Eddie ought not to go to Kansas if she cannot arrange things for him to come back here to school next year she says he ought to stay with Mother. is Frank going back next Fall? I do wish their home was not so far from all the rest of us. 
Cynthia is having severe sweating spells now far about a week something as she had some years ago when she was beginning to gain We hope they are favorable. Her head seems to have less pressure when she sweats profusely. She is some weaker & her stomach troubles her some. Will write again. William is better than when I wrote last. 
Hastily yours, S.A.E.P.

Hillsdale Dec 7/76

Dear Jennie,

  We were almost startled as well as relieved by hearing from home today. We were relieved as we had been anxiously expecting a letter for several days and we were startled by receiving three letters at once. Two of them were mailed the fifth and the sixth of Dec. This last one was from Mother and written Nov 30. I wonder if somebody forgot to put it in the mail? The other two were from you. We feel anxious and troubled about Anna. Poor child, she has been over taxing herself all last spring and summer

in margins
is most bed time so I leave you. Love to all. Good night. 

Sarah and Wm. 

Tell Mathew that we have enough money now - a good deal more than enough to take us home. 
Sat. 9 - We had a cold night. Mon. 5 below zero this morning the coldest they have seen since they have been in Mich. 
Wm. does not breathe quite so well. He got a good letter from Mary yesterday She sent him some medicine and tried to encourage him. I wish we knew how Anna is this cold day. Tell me how the weather is with you and how cold it is.

to say the least. How I wish I could see her and wait on her and comfort her a little. I am sorry Mary Jane is going to leave you so soon. I was in hopes you were going to have a good chance to rest. I feel thankful the Cen. is fairly off your hands. Of course you will miss it and feel lost and lonely without it at first, but it was too much of a burden especially as Anna is so feeble and tired out. I hope we did not do the wrong thing in coming away, I don't know as I could have started if I had known she was going to be sick. William is pretty comfortable now. He went down town today and got our letters. He is feeling better now for a few days than he has since we came here. He breathes pretty freely and sleeps much better. He did not sleep much when he had the asthma so badly. We thought of staying a few

weeks longer to see how he would be and how we would like it here, especially as our friends here are so anxious to have us stay, but if you need us home or if you think we had better come sooner be sure and let us know. William says that he is very thankful to you all for saying that you would be glad to see us back again. I am glad to be able to be with Elizabeth a little and to help her some. She seems to enjoy having us here. They are all very kind and make us as comfortable as they can. I hope you are not very lonely; who sleeps in the study? Does Mr. Daves board at Lewis'? and where is Stephen? Wm says 'Tell Anna she would be all right if she had me back in the study to keep the spooks off nights and to quarrel with er a little now and then.' he wants to know how Tom gets along and can he get

up without help? Wm wants to know if the family have moved into their new house back of the shed. I wonder if John Eddie remembers the little ?pasteboard thread unclear he made for Elizabeth in Lewistown? She had used it ever since and has got it yet. How does he get long in school? Is he most ready for college? have any of you seen our little new nephew? Please mention how they get along when you write. How is Frank Anna? Give our love to Jane Esther. Hattie is a good deal better but she is very weakly and does not have much appetite. I am glad you got some oysters for Anna. They are 25 cents a can here. You must try to coax her to eat all she can and keep up good courage. We feel very thankful to you and Mother for writing to us so often. We shall be anxious now until we get another letter. It

Hillsdale, Jan. 12, 1877

Dear Sister Jennie, 

 Yours of Jan 6 we received day before yesterday. I wrote to J. Eddie that afternoon and intended to have written a few words to you but I sent the letter with the first opportunity. We were glad to hear that dear Mother is getting along as well and we judge from the tone of your letter that you all feel pretty bright and cheerful. We have not yet decided just what to do about going home; we have not much courage to stay till summer as we have lost our faith in Michigan air. We have heard of one man from

in top margin:
this winter? give our love to them both. Wm. says "tell them I am the same old chap." We hope to get another letter from home tomorrow or Monday. I hope mothers cough is better. Tell Mary it is time she should write to us again. I suppose it will not do to expect too much from Anna. I wrote to Glyn this week. Give our love to Lewis and family. Does Maggie succeed in going to school this cold weather. 
Love to all from 
Sarah and William.

here who lives in the fine woods now, and is much better of the asthma than when in Hillsdale. We intend to inquire more about him, but we do not feel very hopeful that Wm. would be much better there. I wish we were safe here in Steuben, but perhaps it is better as it is. We dread the journey a good deal this cold weather. They are building a temporary bridge at Ashtabula. I think they expect to have it ready so that the cars can pass over it in two or three weeks and perhaps sooner. the passengers, baggage &c. are now carried around in sleighs. We are having a long spell of pretty cold stormy weather even here in Mich. There has been good sleighing for several weeks. I think they had only about one week of sleighing last winter. It will probably be better for the fruit and crops next summer to have so much snow now. The

was two above zero this morning at sunrise. We had a hard spell with the asthma last Sat. and Sun. He is much better now and if it were pleasant he would be able to go out for a little walk, but it is too cold and stormy. My teeth are much better though they still pain me some. Elizabeth is about the same; some days very lame indeed and then a little better. On the whole we do not think she has got any worse for the last few weeks. I hope she will feel better when the warm weather comes and she can get out a little. How is it about the Cen. our number has not come yet. We feel a little anxious lest the Chicago bag was an ill-fated train at Ashtabula and was burned. If so, it will be a great loss, but we hope it was not started soon enough for that. A good deal of the mail

was lost there as we see by the papers. Is there any word in Michigan who takes the Cen? William would be very glad if he could come across a welshman. Do they observe the work of prayer in our church? The weather is quite unfavorable, I find, at least it is here. I am glad Anna is able to ride out a little and that she is some better. How does Tim get along, going through the snow? Did Richard get a letter from William? Tell him that he wrote to him some time ago and we are expecting an answer.
Johnny expects to be married before a great while. - sometime in March I believe, to a Miss Bentley from Ohio. She was attending school here last term so we got some acquainted with her. She seems to be a pleasant kindhearted girl and we hope will make him a good wife. - How is Hugh Jones

Home Aug. 26, 1889.

Dear Sisters,
Jennie's letter with the $5. came last evening. I hope you did not cramp yourselves. We will try to keep it to pay John Eddie's fare to N.Y. We are trying to pay up some little bills that were left, as we can. Robbie paid us another $5. making $10. since we came from Turin, and Mrs. J.R. Griffiths paid us for the Spring bed they had. So you see we have a little coming. How do you get along? We are a little disappointed to hear that the schools begin quite so soon. We shall miss J.E. so much. We went yesterday to see Ellen Davies and had a nice time. Tomorrow we intend to go to Camp Meeting. We have invited Laura to ride with us. Carroll has 
top margin:
make her visit pleasant if she should come now. J.E. says that the announcement of the opening of the school is to be published in the N.Y. dailies for Sept. 1st — so please get one, and find out for certain. Do you want us to send any thing with him? Have you heard any thing more from cousin Lizzie Williams? Our baby was three weeks old yesterday. Libbie is getting along pretty well, but is not very strong — she had a very tedious hard time when she was sick her mother has been with her since Monday — went home today. They expect to get along alone the rest of this week. Mrs. Hughes

have been. He and John Eddie are washing the wagen this afternoon, so I suppose we will go in style. I wish you both could enjoy it with us. There is an excursion today to the Thousand Islands and Lewis and Jane have gone. They were very much afraid to have him go but he was so very anxious that they were obliged to yield to his wishes. Perhaps it will not hurt him but he seems very weak for such a journey. If he knew that had had the hemorrhage he would probably be more fearful of overdoing. He is gaining but not very fast. Maggie was here this afternoon, and she said he looked better yesterday then since he has been sick. they have named the baby Lewis and his grand-father is very much pleased. Try and find out just when the College term opens, as we would like to keep J.E. as long as we can. If he will have to be there against the 6th, the time will be very short indeed. Has Mrs. Jones given up the idea of coming up this summer? I wish she was here to go with us to Camp Meeting. Cannot she come against the Gymanfa?. I think we could 
left margin:
has promised to come again next week to wash, and perhaps stay here two or three days. Love from Sarah & Anna

Gymanfa: Welsh for Assembly

Hillsdale Nov. 19

Dear Sister Jennie,

 I have just finished this little piece of poetry. I am sorry I have been so long about it but my mind has been so tossed about that I find it hard to steady it down to any thing as I want to. I wish I could have written better. If you do not think it will be best to put it in the Cen. let me know and I will try again. If you or Anna or any of you would like to change it you are welcome to do it. William has been sick most of the time since we have been with the asthma. He took cold and the weather has 

right margin:
so staid J. Eddie and Maggie like their school. 
left margin and top:
to softening of the lower part of the spinal canal or marrow. She sends her love and says she will write soon. She has been so poorly it has been hard for her to write, but she is a little better now. Dr. speaks rather hopefully but he owns that it is impossible to tell what the result will be. My health is good. I was weight last Thur 103 pounds. Where is Anna? down low in the poor nineties, I suppose. I hope she enjoyed her visit in Turin. I am sorry you did not get more good from your visit in Utica I am very sorry I could not help you there. I am Give our love to Mary.

been very unfavorable and his journey tired him a good deal. He has been no worse than he used often to be at home, still I feel most discouraged. I am afraid he climate here will not cure him — but perhaps it will help him — we can tell before long. He breathed very hard yesterday but is much better today. It has been misty and cloudy a good deal of the time; today it is quite warm and rains a very little. We got Mother's letter Sat. We feel very thankful to her for writing so often and for telling us so much news. I am glad Mother Prichard has visited you. We are glad of all the news you can give us from Glyn. Elizabeth is pretty well as to her general health but it is very hard for her to get around she is so lame. The Dr. thinks is is Paralisis — and that there is a tendency 
left margin and top:
Jane had Richard and every one of the dear ones at home and at Glyn. I will write to Mother soon. We had a good deal more snow than you did, but prehaps you will catch it next time. It is all gone now. I wish I could help with the Cen. Love to Lewis & family from Sister Sarah

no date
Dear Sister Jennie,

  As William has been writing to Anna I thought I would add a few words to you. We were glad to receive the Cenhadwr yesterday morning and to know that you were over with the hurry once again. I am sorry you got so tired out. I am afraid your visit here did not do you much good you had so much to do when you got home. Your letter this morning was very welcome. You and Anna must have had a hard time with the serving and folding. I wish I could have been there to help you. William is much better than when I wrote last so of course I feel 

left margin to top:
went out once. Why dont you keep your class in S.S.? I should be anxious to know how you get along how many attend and who has y class. I shall miss it very much. If Anna has it I hardly think they will miss me. It would be so nice if she could get some of the little ones to sing. We had a letter from Hattie a few days ago urging us to hasten our visit so as to be there commencement time - next week I think. The letter was forwarded from Remsen. I have not answered it yet. Of course we will not go just yet as we want to try Marys medicine a little longer. Why dont Anna write?
Love to Mother and all    Sarah.

more contented. He was many days unable to go out at all. He cant walk much of any yet but we have been several times in the St. cars and it seems to do him good. His arm is quite sore yet. The vaccination did not work on me. Cynthia is about as usual. Mary is well but very busy. I hope she will get along better now. John Eddie is quite well and a great deal of company for us. Mary got him two new shirts (light Calico) ready made, they cost 2,50. I could not possibly make them for him as we had more than we could rightly do in the house. He ought to have a new hat and a pair of shoes. I hardly know what we had better do. My health is good but I dont like New York very well. I dont think I could ever feel at home here. We went at the Welsh church Sunday afternoon Eddie stayed home to keep house. We only

Dear Jennie I am sorry you perceive no effect from the medicine, but it is pretty Soon yet. & you have had to work very hard since going home. Perservere one week on & one week off yet awhile Were glad to see Cen. & to get a letter also from you Cen came in Co. with a letter from Eddie Cynthia seems to feel quite comfortable. It is nearing time for for Eddie to come home from school & I don't know but we will go down to see Stewart's Store. We failed to see the Mason's.

parade today, partly because I was afraid the crowd would be too much for the feeble ones. & partly because we could not leave the house alone. The things you bought for me make the house much pleasanter & more homelike, & we are thus often reminded of you Hope you will be able to make me another visit before long, Wish Mother could come down. Mrs. Jones intends to Make you a visit this summer. Wish I could go with - her. Good by now with - ever so much love from us five to you all. Tell Anna I wish she was here to make garden. Your loving sister Mary.-

Wed. afternoon Sept. 4.
Dear Jennie,
Anna Hattie and I have just come in from a pleasant walk. Anna is resting her and as it is almost supper time she will not be likely to write much more in this letter as we wish to send it to the office tonight. We are enjoying our visit here very much and I believe the rest are to, at least they seem to. How do the Good Templars get along? do you go down as often as you used to? supposing you write and tell your "worthy" sister something about it. - On coming back from our walk today we called at the post office but did not get any letter from home as we expected. The truth is, I believe we expect too much of you, of course you are all very busy and it is hard to get time to write often to us. Mary has been very faithful so far, and we are thankful for it, it does us so much good to hear from you. Accept much love from us all. - Sarah.

Tues. Sep. 3.
Dear sister Jennie,
Elizabeth talks of getting her a new black silk dress something like yours, or rather of sending for Mr. Butler to get it for her. She would like you to send a sample of yours, in your next letter, and please tell us how wide it is, and the price per yard. Also how many yards did you get? I forgot to mention about this in my letter yesterday, that is the reason I have commenced another letter so soon. Another favor, - will you please get from Jane, and send her pattern for embroidering slippers. Hattie wants to make her father a pair against he comes home. Send it soon, if possible. (Another favor. - Mrs. Butler would like to have the receipt for making Mr. Edwards emplings. We would be so glad if you would copy it and send it.
[[Transcriber's note: the first transcriber was not clear on whose receipt it was, but said it was for "dumplings". I can read "Mr. Edwards" but no way is there a D in the next word. "Emplings" are a thing in 2020, you can look it up, but they are an Indonesian snack. Wales is about as exotic as immigration got circa 1880 so I think "dumpling" is what was meant after all...]]

Miss. Everett

Dear Madam, (Sis set me up to communicating this so, as you might suppose.) I feel better now as you may very well know from the looks of the envelope. This is the first I have - directed for some years. They are almost ready for supper and this must go immediately after so I can write but a

few words. I am sitting up in bed now but I am tired, so please excuse the pen and accept the pencil. Oh, Jennie you are such a great girl for writing me such a grand long note in answer to my little one; may I hope you will be so good this time? But what in the world do you want with that hair? Is yours coming out? I had a first

rate visit from the Kellogg's I do wish you could have enjoyed it with me. Mr. H. said he would call on you sometime to see how you make out in housekeeping. So prepare!

 Sarah. ----

few words. I am sitting up in bed now but I am tired, so please excuse the pen and accept the pencil. Oh, Jennie you are such a great girl for writing me such a grand long note in answer to my little one; may I hope you will be so good this time? But what in the world do you want with that hair? Is yours coming out? I had a first rate visit from the Kellogg's I do wish you could have enjoyed it with me. Mr. H. said he would call on you sometime to see how you make out in housekeeping. So prepare! Sarah. ----

Thurs eve, Home, Feb am.
Dear Jennie 

  We received the note you wrote Monday this morning and sent you sheep-skin to the village this afternoon, to go by the stage tomorrow morning so I hope you will get it before Mrs Baker goes home.  We got your other letter also tonight, the one that you wrote this morning.  I am sorry that you are so busy, Jennie, that you cannot write us longer letters.  I am afraid you have too much to do and that is the reason you don't write more. 
  Cannot you and Robert come home next Sat?  I should think you might, now, you are not

in pencil, top margin:
Jennie get a dozen envelopes for wedding cards and bring with you Sat.

teaching.  Do come if you can, it may be the last chance you will get for a great while.  Sarah wants you to get two or three quires of small letter paper when you come: not such paper as this is, but better shaped sheets than this, if you please.  I wrote to you a week or two ago, but I fear you did not get it as you do not say any thing about in your notes to Mother.  Sis and Eddy wrote some time before that,  but we don't know as you received that.  Sarah wishes to know whether any thing has been done about her bed yet the springs have got out of order, and she wants Robert to see if it can be fixed. We had a letter from Uncle John Monday night, saying that

his family had arrived there safe and that they were to-gether once more.  I can write no more now, in haste, Anna P.S. Don't you think I am smart, Jennie, I have written you two pages of foolscap.  This is a piece that Sis cut off from the end of a letter she is writing in order to make it smaller, and I, your economical sister took what she had cast away to write my letter on. - your sister Anna -
Dearest Jennie - I received a letter from Dr Grafs this week with a  wedding card for you and another for me enclosed.  The card tells the tale: he is a married man and as he writes a happy one too.  His wife is the only daughter of a minister.  I have not yet answered his

letter, but I hope to be able to in a few days.  I believe I will send your card for fear you will not come home very soon.  Now Jennie dear why don't you write to me?  Have you almost forgotten your poor sick sister?  or have you quite forgotten how very much she prizes letters from her dear Jennie?  We had a letter from Mary last Sat night All is getting along well I should think.  Her health has been decidedly improving since she went to Hadley she thinks.  But she said she had not had a line from either Robert or you.  What is the reason?  Margaret is much better this week.  I am improving slowly.  The rest of us are pretty well.  Sarah M wants you to get her 1/8 of a yard or linen lawn; and she would like to have you get six more skeins of white floss and three of delicate pink.  Can you get some more patterns for marking?  She wants me to mark an edge an "chickens fixins", and any others that you can get.  Don't you think you can visit us soon?  If you cannot, please write to me.  Sarah.

Remsen Jan the 11 1875 
Edward Everett  
Dear friend Edward 

  I hav took this pleasure in wrightng you a few lines to let you know that we are all well and we are driving Srip? every day al most she is getting well very fast now. I don't think that she will be any worse it storme very hard yesterday and we been home all day and to day we bee opning the road that is all I have to say now bcose it is 9 oclock good night 

Wright soon lov to all 
William E Jones 
Steuben 
Oneida Co

Dear Eddie, 

  Your friend William E Jones has invited me to write a little to you in his letter and I am very glad to do it. He is leaning on the table close by eating molasses candy and if you were here you could go to the little pantry in the hall and help yourself. How do you get along any way, you little rogue? I would really like to get hold of you tonight and give you a good shaking or count your ribs or something. By the way how many ribs have you got? you never would keep still so I could count them, ask Anna to try. Perhaps now you have got to be a city chap you can keep still. Bill forgot to tell you the news in his letter. He wants me to say that he went to the

Eisteddfod New Years.  It was the first  time that he ever was in Utica and  he had a good time and his plate  of oyster soup. What did you do  Christmas and New Years?  tell us all  about it when you write.  Did you  get any presents?  Did you see any Christmas trees?  How is Anna's arm?  tell her  to put two eggs in that jell cake.  I  though I had written the recipe all right.  It is after ten and I suppose you are in bed sound asleep.  We both send love to you all.  Write as soon as you can to  your affectionate aunt Sarah A.E.P. 
Ask Anna if I had better let some of the first flowers on the Princess go to seed. They are blossoming nicely.

March 17 1879   

Dear John Eddie 

  We did not get your card  until Sat.  Indeed we only got our mail  twice last week, (Tues. and Sat.) as George  went away Monday and William was so  poorly.  Mrs R.R. Roberts was buried  last Tuesday, and Anna went down afoot  to the funeral.  The roads were so soft  they could not take the horses any  farther than Frank Evans.  Men & boys  had to draw the sleighs from there to  Fairchild.  William is getting better  slowly but he does not get over this  spell very fast.  He finds it pretty  tough work to do the chores.  You  ask if we would like to have you come home before the term closes.

Would it be much of a loss to you if you should? We need you very much and if you would not be losing a great deal we would like to have you come as soon as you can. But you must use your own judgement and if you think it best to wait till the term closes we will by to do as well as we can. A week from tomorrow night Prof. Cain is going to give a concert in Remsen. He is having singing schools for the children every day. Is he the one who gave a concert in Turin? We have not been to see Paulina? yet and they have not been here. Please write soon what you decide to do. We shall be very glad to see you when you do come. Love to all. Affectionately S.A.E.P.

Sat Morning
Dear Nephew: Robbie came here yesterday afternoon, and asked at once if you were at home. He stayed and made us quite a visit. Had left Libbie at Mrs. Pierce's. He still left that $5, Jones would do for us. had just learned where he is staying. He intends seeing him today or Monday and will report. Was it profanity or obscenity in his language that Mr. Roberts refered to? If the former we think he would not be apt to indulge in our presence. If the latter, he would not at all. Robbie thinks we would not have trouble with the cows next month even if we should be alone. I do not think we would. I hope we can get along without your coming home this April. Still keep close up with your studies so that you can

come if necessary. We will perhaps get a buggy? to run errands &c &c. I feel quite courageous especially after seeing Robbie. He says the cows are in splendid condition. Anna is still gaining Sat up to tea yesterday P.M. & slept well last night.  Jennie pretty well this morning & I first rate also cousin M. 
Much love, 
Your Aunt 

 A?

Tues a.m. - Cousin Mary went yesterday on the 2 pm train. M. and I took her to the depot - with the mud sled. It was better going than we feared - rained after we got home then turned cold - and is

quite wintry this a.m. Anna and Mary slept well last night. A is now taking her breakfast. Frank Cook and his brother Charlie came here sat evening to see about a place - Charlie would have liked to come here bu he had an offer for $18 per month for the eight summer months and did not feel willing to come here for what Frank gets. We liked him and had we felt we could pay what he asked should have hired him. Robbie advised us to get a boy or an old man who would not ask much wages. He said our work was not more than enough for such help. We hope to hear

from Robbie in a day or two. Do you know a man by the name of Hugh Griffith? John R. told Caroline he thought he would do for us. We have not seen those Welsh boys. Hope to have some word from you soon. We also will write often and keep you posted. Mary had a letter from Johnny which she found on the table this a.m. They are well and happy and useful it seems in the church there. They are to have a donation this week I believe. On the Christmas tree there were about $20 worth of presents for the pastor and wife. The people have also kept them supplied with meat for the winter. They have painted the parsonage and added quite a number of books to the S.S. library since Johnny has been there. Robbie said that man to buy hens for 4 had but very few - shall we try for G.G.'s?  with much love M & A

George asked me this morning if we wanted a Mem. Said that the man who worked for D? Price last summer. (From the Old Country) wanted a place. Said he was bright but not very strong & he thought, would come reasonable. What do you think of him? What do you know  Did you go to Cousin Nellie's funeral last Sabbath? I have written to her mother.

Had a letter this morning from Johnny Butler, written with a type writer. one which he got for half price. They are well and prospering. 
Love from all.

Clinton W. C. Nov 18, 1881
My dear Brother

 As Dr. Grafs is going to the city and will be in your way I thought I would not let the opportunity pass, with sending you a note. I hope you will be coming out to see me again before a great while, for I have a great deal that I want to say to you; and there is one thing in particular, that I would like to have a talk with you about, but I cannot do it by writing, for until I see you I know nothing certainly of how matters stand. But I will just mention it here, and then wait patiently until I can see you and have a private interview with you; I suppose you know what and who I have reference to; it is Miss P. and the attentions which you are paying to her. Are you in earnest, and have you any serious motive in thus cultivating her acquaintance, and seeking or at least encouraging her affection by your attentive manner towards her? If so, if you are in earnest, I have nothing to say; no objections to make, as I know of; but if you are not, my dear brother, let me encourage you to be circumspect; you are not fondly aware how very sensitive and easily won a lady's heart is. I know that you above all others would shrink with horror from even the idea of trifling with any one's feelings, but remember, you may do it without intending it if you are not on your guard. Perhaps I do not judge illegible not knowing more about it, and that is the reason several words illegible would you. Pardon me for illegible

embossed seal  Dear Sister Mary, 

 Thanks, many thanks to you for your long=expected, long=looked=for, and therefore much=prized letter which has at length arrived. At length, I say; would you be supprised if I tell you that I almost dispaired of getting it at all I was beginning to think that you had, in some way, imbibed a sad dislike for writing, which you could not overcome even to write to me. But the reception of your well filled letter has dispeled all such ideas and I again begin to cherish the hope of hearing from you quite often, shall I be disappointed? -- You say that Father and Mother are coming to Utica today, but you do not mention one word about them coming to see me. I hardly know whether to expect them or not. It seems to me when any of you come to Utica you are almost here, but I suppose it is not so; eight miles makes a good deal of difference when any one is in a hurry, and therefore I am very much afraid that they will not be able to come. But I will hope for the best, and wait as patiently as I can and see what will happen. — You do not say very? much in your letter about its being so near the time for you to go East; perhaps you are in hopes that I will forget all about it, but never fear! my memory has not entirely forsaken me yet; the school commences just three weeks tomorrow. And then you will go, and I shall be left without either of you, my dear sisters But we must be contented, and do as duty bids us. It will be lonely at home without

you, dear girls, dont you know it? Mother, and Anna and Siss will be lonly. Cheer them up as much as you can before you leave them, and telll them that I hope that I will soon be able to come home to assist them and keep them company. But say, are you not coming to see me until just before you go? Do tell me when you write next just what you are going to do about it  Will you leave home before Monday? what day will you come here? I want to know how near you are ready to start, and if you are going to be well prepared. Tell Anna that the task of writing to me will fall upon her when you are gone, as she will then be, as Jane is now, the "oldest daughter at home." — 

 I suppose you think that I did not mean to write much when I to such a small piece of paper and indeed I did not. I thought that I would let you have a little letter this time, and not try to write much, as you advised me to do in your letter, to see if I could not do it without getting tired. My health is improving. I feel better this week than I have, I think, at all. I am in better spirits, which you know is a great thing. I feel as if I was realy going to get well! do you wonder that I feel good? Give my love to my little Eddy and tell him, I was going to say not to forget me but I know he will not, but tell him to think of Sarah very often and be a good boy. O how I wish I could be with him! Give my love to Gwen and to the Thomas girls and to all the rest of my friends that you see meeting time. Write to me again dear Mary, as soon as you can wont you? and tell Lany? to too Cant you come and see me before you start? Write and tell me. Love to all. Your sister Sarah

Clinton, Jan. 10, 1852.__

Dear Sister Mary, 

 The news that you had come home was as sudden, as it was unexpected; but the pleasure that i felt on hearing you were so near me was not unmixed with anxiety. Mother says in her note, that you are unwell with the influenza, but how unwell, and whether you are going back next term, she does not say. If you have not written already, I hope you will as soon as you receive this, for I shall be quite uneasy until I hear further from you. You are coming to see me before you go back, are you not? Oh, you must. I cant bear to think of you, going away without my seeing you. Write to me, and say you will certainly come, and then I will feel so much better. - Cousins Elisabeth and Alexander, and their cousin, Miss Bowen, came to see me yesterday afternoon; I had not seen Elisabeth but once before since I came here. We had a very pleasant visit. They brought the things that mother sent to me. Tell her, I like them very much indeed; they are just what I wanted. I shall be very glad to get this long sack, although I did not ask for it. I have got it on today, it fits well, and feels so comfortable; and those night caps too, I needed them very much; if ma had been home, I cold hardly have told her better what I wanted. She has sent me such a good supply

of caps, that I do not think I shall need any more until I get well. That skirt is almost too pretty to wear in bed, I think; but I mean to be sitting up before it is half worn out. But if I talk so much about my clothes you will think I am getting proud. Give my love to Aunt Sarah, and tell her I am very much obliged to her for being so kind as to make my drapes; and especially for making them so nice. I guess she knows that sick folks like to see everything look pretty. –– How did you leave Jane, was she quite well? but what in the world made you come home, it must of been a very sudden thought that you took, for I had a letter from Jane a little more than a week ago, and she did not say one word about it. I cannot understand it unless you are sick, but Oh I hope that is not it. But perhaps you got a little homesick, was that it, Mary dear? Write to me and tell me al about it. Ann sends her love to you and says if you move here she would pack you and soon cure you up; she is a good faithful girl; you must love her for being so kind to me. Oh, Mary, is it not strange that everybody is so good to me? I am still improving; it seems as if I could feel myself getting better from day to day. Be sure to come to see me. Write soon. Give my love to all our dear family, yourself included, of course. Your aff. sister, Sarah.

Clinton, unclear S April 25, 1852

Dear Jennie and Mary, 

 Brother John has been out here again; he came last evening between seven and eight and left this morning about five. Rather a short visit, but it was as sweet as it was short. He is after some bees that he had sought from a man in this village for his orchard, which I suppose he has told you about before this. Wont we have a delightful time if we can visit him some few years hence, in the fall, when the apples are ripe? John brought me a likeness of his and gave it t me, I had not had one of his here before but I had told him that I wanted it a good any times: I do not think I ever saw a better one of him than this one is, it seems almost perfect; the expression is so good. 
 Oh, girls, I believe I will give you a little description of two of the girls that are now in my room for they are talking and laughing so that I can hardly think of anything else. They are the only young girls that are here (of patients, I mean) excepting myself. I will begin with Gertrude Sawyer as she is the oldest. She is about eighteen. She is not pretty, I don't think, but she has got pretty eyes and teeth: she is good-hearted but Oh 

top margin:
It was Kate that directed my two last letters, perhaps she will direct this and perhaps Gertrude and perhaps the Dr. will. I dont know yet if Dr. knew I was writing I guess he would send his love or respects, but he does unclear and probably will not until this is finished and sealed. They say they have not heard from you at home in three weeks. I suppose you are too busy but you will soon have time unclear I hope. John wanted to know if you were not coming home this vacation. I told him that you said in our letter that you did not think you would It is so cold and stormy today I do not think I shall be able to go out. Write and tell me how you have got along with your examinations. —

 Sarah

she is wild, full of fun and mischief too sometimes; she is a little too coquetish for me; I think that is one of her greatest faults. — I had to stop writing to take my sits bath. I have got all through mow, but feel quite tiered so I guess I will not write much more. Perhaps I will go on with my discription sometime again; for Gertrude and Kate and I are together so much that I would like to have you know them as much as you can from what I can tell you. I wish you knew Kate Burnham, I think you would be interested in her, at least; she is wild also, so you see your sober Sarah is in lovely company. Kate is about fifteen, sister Anna's age; she is taller than Anna a good deal, I should think. She is very fair, light blue eyes, very light hair curling in natural ringlets, in fact, I think she is quite pretty. She is a little witch, full of innocent fun and girlish wildness. Gertrude has dark blue eyes and dark hair something the color of Lewis's. But I did not intend to discribe them todya I almost forgot myself. The first bell has rung for dinner and I expect Ann in every minute with mine. Now be sure and write me some good long

Dear Sister Mary, 

  Henry is about to start, and I have but a moment to write. –– Nearly two long months have passed since you went away; how many more shall be suffered to follow them ere you return? Dont you think you can come to see us before long? But I will not press you, for I would not have you leave Sister and her dear little John Henry for the sake of gratifying me with a visit.

Oh my sweet dear nephie! how I love him although I have never seen him. Can it be that the warm bursting heart at that pure xxx shall ever be chilled by the cold smiles at this unfeeling world? or shall his bright soul ever be stained by sin?
 Oh my his guardian angel how 
 And far from his pure spotless shown?
 Each opening thought that might alure?
 His soul from what is bright and pure

But I must hasten. –– My health continues slowly to improve, but I am not able to sit up any more than 15 or 20 minuts at a time. I am not able to make any my back is so bad. 
Transcriber's note: moral: don't try to write poetry when in a hurry to make the post. Not sure which words go on which lines. Is there an English major in the house?

Most of the time I feel quite cheerful and think that i am going to get well in a little while; but still I feel almost tempted to be discouraged it takes so long. Cousin Elizabeth is a great deal of company for me, she is not very well she has not nearly regained her strength. She says you must call and see Mary as soon as you can; she will be so lonly there all alone. Our Jr? meeting is this week. I hoped to be able to atend, but no. — I must close for Henry is starting with much love to you and Elizabeth and all, Sarah.
