Dear Mary, 

 I received your letter the 26  I was very sorry that I caused so much anxiety by delaying to acknowledge the reception of the money so long; hope the letter Mrs. S. and I wrote last week was duly received. Was glad to hear that you had been black-berrying Next year, perhaps - perhaps. - who knows? my hopes are on tip toe peering over the rail into an aparantly bright future. O, shall I ever be well? Thy will, O, my God, be done. May a hearty, Amen, echo from

each of your hearts. - But why did not Sis and Letitia go with you  How are they and you, Aunt S. Pa, Mrs. Lewis and the birds? and how does my precious Eddy employ himself for a living? - Why what would Dr. say if he knew how much I have written? Good by for today. —

Tuesday. 20. — O, I do feel so well this afternoon: This morn. before 6 I walked out to the piazza, walked across it and then the whole length of the hall past the sitting room. looked out into the garden and then came back to bed having stopped on the way to swing. Can any of you girls tell a larger story than that? ask Jennie if she can remember what time it was. I didn't have a sinking spell after it either.  O, Mary, I have had a tooth

ache, and what is better I had it pulled. It had not ached long enough to weaken me much, yet I suppose that altogether it put me back a few days. When the dentist took it out I believe I was much more scared than hurt. I had a spasm but it did not last long; and I do not remember that I lost one walk for either the aching or pulling. Dr walks with me 2 a day. 

 Good bye; good bye. I have written enough for today. thats so. Love to all. Write soon. —Sarah.—

New Hampton Sept. 10. 1867? 1869?.

Dear sister Mary, 

 As I am not famous for writing long letters this sheet looks rather large to me, but as I am not obliged to fill it it does not trouble me a great deal. We were very much relieved yesterday buy receiving Jennies letter; we were becoming quite anxious lest some of you were sick or all tried out with Cen. and the rest of the work. I am glad you are getting along so well and would be very glad if I could help you How do you get along Mary, do you have any time with your books? and how is your head? How is Mother? I dreamed last night that she was most sick she was so tired. Tell baby I dreamed about him too last night and he was as full of life and talk as ever. 
 Anna has not been quite as well for a few days. She has taken some cold which affects her eyes and head and throat a good deal. 

left margin:
Mary, could you send me the pattern of my little sack, the one I made last. I believe it is in the patterns bag, marked "from S. Syman." Perhaps you could mark it out on a newspaper with a pencil, and we could cut it. Did Robbie get some papers from Hattie? She sent him two or three "Myrtles." Elizabeth intends to write soon but has not time today. Does any body remember to take care of the cucumbers, or are there note to take care of? 

Anna.

She has taken Mercurious but it does not seem to affect her. Today she is feeling some better and we hope she will soon begin to gain again. Her bowels are more regular, especially for the last two weeks, and her appetite is all the time better than before we started although some days it is not so good as it is others. I try to tell you just how Anna is as nearly as I can but you know I am not a very good hand. The weather has been unfavorable most of the time since we have been here, cold and cloudy if not rainy. I will write again in a few days. Elizabeth and Anna and I are going out to make a little walk this afternoon, and I must go and get ready. Anna has been resting. — 

 I hope that mother and you will be able to go to Utica to the meeting, and that you will hear Mr. Jones preach. Write and tell us all about the Cymanfa, what ministers are there and which of our folks go where &c. Tell Sis to tell me about the Camp Meeting if she knows any thing about it. I wonder if Cynthia thinks that because she takes my place in making fire mornings she must also gill it in not writing letters. — she must have some reason for being so still. 

cymanfa = assembly

— We have come back from our walk and pleasant call. Anna is lying down resting, perhaps she will not write this time as I am anxious to send this to the office tonight and she is rather tired. She seems better this afternoon. We called at Mrs. Ware's to see Capt. Davis curiosities. He is a sea captain as perhaps you know, he and his family have gone on a voyage now. We saw a great varity of shells and different things that interested us much.

Mary did you get that little peice of light blue cloth like Hatties dress that Anna sent in her letter to you about two weeks ago? Elizabeth wanted you to look in your book and then give your advice. Would you think best to color it red or green or dark blue or what. 
 Here are two conundrums for Robbie. How much does a fool weigh generally? A simple ton.When may a man be said to have a vegetable time-piece? When he gets a potato clock (when he gets up at eight oclock.) Baby, there were four little children playing horse on the sidewalk just under our window this afternoon, and it made us think of you ever so much. One little boy a little bigger than you they called Eddie.. He was just about as noisy as you. Another boy

who was the horse got away once or twice and they had great times trying to catch him:

 I hope you will not leave us so long without a letter again as you did this time. try not to be uneasy about us (that is Anna) and we will write pretty often. Give our love to Gwen and John D. and to Mrs. Griffiths folks by the church, and to Mrs Hugh Jones and family indeed remember us kindly to all our friends. How is Jane? I hope she has got well before this. Give our love to them all and also to Robert Hughs and Jane. Tell Lewis that we were sorry that we were not a minute or two later starting the morning we came away or else that he was a little earlier so that we could have spoken to him and thanked him for his trouble. Supper is ready, so good bye. Love to all. — Sarah A E.

P.S. Dont think of us as eating supper all the time because we have got through for today! A. S.

 Mary, we have missed your letters for the past two or three weeks. What is the reason? Can it be our fault? I hope you will not neglect us entirely if we are a little slow about answering your letters sometimes they are just as welcome. I suppose that tomorrow some of you will be going to Utica to meeting. hope you will have good meetings, and pleasant weather for them. Tell Baby I was very much pleased with his little writing book. I think he had better write a letter to Hattie next time, she wants a letter from him. 

left margin:
I have been having a cold and so not feeling very well but am getting over it. I think. Wish I could see you all tonight. — I hope John D. & Gwen will get the love all right this time Love, love to all from Anna.

New Hampton, Oct. 1, 1867.

Dear sister Mary

  We received a letter from you Saturday containing 10 dollars. we have now $30. for our journey home. This will be enough if we do not have any trouble in any way in unlooked for expense. We would feel a good deal better if we had a little more but we dont know as it will be worth while for you to send any, as perhaps we can get along comfortably with what we have. If you do send another $5. had we not better yet $1. or so worth of thread, it is only six cents a spool here and you know this is a good deal cheaper than we can get it at home. Please mention about it when you write . And so, Mary, you have really decided to 

top margin:
Anna is going slowly and I hope she will still continue to after we get home.

go to New York. On that account I wish very much that we were at home now to be with you a little while before you go and to help you get ready. Have you secured a boarding place there? I suppose you will want one of our trunks. How I do wish I could be home for half an hour this afternoon so that I could get the news in a natural state before it is cut and dried and all shrunk up suitable to be put in a letter. 
Elizabeth had a letter yesterday from Mr. Butler from Paris. He thought then that he should sail on the 12 of Oct. instead of the 23 of Nov. as had been intended. Mrs. Marilla Butler has been sick and Mr. Thomson is so feeble that they will not travel much more and Mr. B. does not care to go without them, so if he could get his ticket changed he would come home before the rest of its party. He said that by the time his letter was in New Hampton he should probably be in Wales and would write from there. So it may be that Mr. Butler will be home in five weeks, and

if he does we hardly know whether we had better stay long enough to see him or not. We had concluded to go home next week, to start from here Thursday Oct. 10. What had we better do, Mary? I suppose if we stay to see Mr. B. we can still get home in time to see you before you start but not in time to help much. At all events we hope to get one more letter from you before we start, and we will write and let you know just when to expect us. E. expects another letter from Mr. Butler in a few days and then he will brobably be able to say definately when he will start. Perhaps it will be better for us to go home next week any way. if you think so do not hesitate to let us know. Be sure to write us as soon as you get this as there will be no time to loose if we start Thursday. We were very glad to get a letter from Lewis and Jane and the children last Saturday. We are not sure as we will have time to write to them again. we will if we can. We are all well. Hoping to get a letter from you Tuesday and to see you very soon, Sarah. A. E.

Remsen, Feb 2, 1872

Dear Sister Mary,

  It seems a long time since we have heard from you and we are getting quite anxious. I dare say it is our fault as we have been very careless about writing you for the last few weeks. The Cen. started this morning, and this afternoon we four girls went off on a tramp. Perhaps you know that there is a road this winter from David Price's right past our house and through the backyard down to the other road. So we took the horse and sleigh and started, Anna and I stopped and spent the afternoon at Henry Thomas'

and Jenni and Cynthia went on to see Mrs. J. G. Jones (Cabla) and called for us on their way home. John Eddie came from school and shared or visit at Athalia's. We had a very pleasant time all of us and received a warm kind welcome at both houses. We had a good letter from Elizabeth this evening and one to me from Hattie. She writes that her health is better but her head still troubles her some. She said she had some medicine from you to be taken thrice times a day but she is so busy with her studies that she did not seem to get time to take it. She intends to keep it till vacation (March) and then cure herself up. She wanted me to tell you when I wrote and says she will write you herself as soon as possible. Sat. morning - I did not finish this last night and as we are going

to send to the P.O. this morning. I will add a few words and let this go. - Cynthia is not very well and we think she aught to take some thing. Most every one remarks that she looks badly. She does not have those spasms very often but she has the unconscious spells quite frequently. much the same as when you were home. She came pretty near having a serious time down at Lewis' the other day. Jane did not know that she had such spells and so of course was much frightened. She thought Sis was going to faint she so pale, and handing her the hartshorn bottle she ran to the pantry for the camphor but before she got back Cynthia (without knowing what she was doing) commenced pouring the hartshorn into her mouth. Jane screamed to her and either that or

the smart in her mouth startled her and she tried to spit it out. We do not think she swallowed any but her throat and mouth were dreadfully sore. She got all over it in a few days, but I thought perhaps you would like to know about it. Did you ever give her the medicine that Dr. Lilienthal advised last Fall? I do not know what it was but but perhaps you will remember. I think some other Dr. spoke to him about it. She is felling pretty well this morning and is going to the village with Jennie. I will enclose in this $5. You can confer money and will send the remainder 1.50 again. In haste Sarah A. Everett

Turin Oct. 15 Mon. eve.

Dear Mary, 

 Two letters came from you today, one, I think, written Friday and the other Sat. I have written to you every day for several days. I wrote to you this morning that Eddie did not rest very well last night - that his bowels pained him some They moved a very little again this forenoon - quite naturally but only a little. He felt quite poorly all morning and I think the Dr. was a little anxious but he is much better this afternoon.
